Mass. Gen. Laws Ch. 186, \u00a7 14.proposition: Plaintiff alleges a cause of action against the Defendant for breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment, as recognized under Massachusetts law, Mass. Gen. Laws Ch. 186, § 14, and relevant case law in Massachusetts including Erickson v. Whistler, 390 Mass. 546 (1983) and Puccio v. Marx, 410 Mass. 438 (1991).

Erickson v. Whistler, 390 Mass. 546 (198.proposition: Plaintiff alleges a cause of action against the Defendant for breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment, as recognized under Massachusetts law, Mass. Gen. Laws Ch. 186, § 14, and relevant case law in Massachusetts including Erickson v. Whistler, 390 Mass. 546 (1983) and Puccio v. Marx, 410 Mass. 438 (1991).
Erickson v. Whistler, 390 Mass. 546 (198.support_reasoning: This opinion concerns medical malpractice and the doctrine of informed consent under Mass. Gen. Laws c. 231, § 60B. It does not involve landlord-tenant law, covenants of quiet enjoyment, Mass. Gen. Laws c. 186, § 14, or any related housing issues. Therefore, it does not provide authority for a cause of action for breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment and is mis-cited for that proposition.
Erickson v. Whistler, 390 Mass. 546 (198.relevant_excerpt: "In Harnish v. Children’s Hosp. Medical Center, 387 Mass. 152 (1982), which was decided after the tribunal’s ruling, we explicitly endorsed the doctrine for the first time, holding that 'a physician’s failure to divulge in a reasonable manner to a competent adult patient sufficient information to enable the patient to make an informed judgment whether to give or withhold consent to a medical or surgical procedure constitutes professional misconduct and comes within the ambit of G. L. c. 231, § 60B.'"

Puccio v. Marx, 410 Mass. 438 (1991).proposition: Plaintiff alleges a cause of action against the Defendant for breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment, as recognized under Massachusetts law, Mass. Gen. Laws Ch. 186, § 14, and relevant case law in Massachusetts including Erickson v. Whistler, 390 Mass. 546 (1983) and Puccio v. Marx, 410 Mass. 438 (1991).
Puccio v. Marx, 410 Mass. 438 (1991).support_reasoning: Puccio v. Marx is a condominium/common-area allocation case under Mass. Gen. Laws c. 183A; it concerns whether a by-law amendment granting exclusive use of common property altered percentage interests without unanimous consent. The opinion does not address landlord–tenant law, residential tenancies, or the statutory covenant of quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14, nor does it mention Erickson v. Whistler or analyze quiet enjoyment as a cause of action. Therefore it does not support the proposition about a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment under Massachusetts landlord–tenant law.
Puccio v. Marx, 410 Mass. 438 (1991).relevant_excerpt: “The master deed, the condominium trust instrument, and G. L. c. 183A, § 5, all require the unanimous consent of the unit owners for any change in the owners’ percentage interest in the common areas. … The amendment therefore violated G. L. c. 183A, § 5 (b), and the terms of the master deed and the condominium trust instrument. Under the master deed and the trust instrument, the amendment is invalid and has no effect.”
